thread.title: Snakes! Watch Leicester sizzle without Ranieri
thread.title_full: Snakes! Watch Leicester sizzle without Ranieri

title: Snakes! Watch Leicester sizzle without Ranieri
text:
Doesn't make players snakes. It was just a relationship that stopped working. — David Preece (@davidpreece12) By the way. Stop with crocodile tears for Ranieri. Job of manager is to keep players focused and together. He failed this season. Badly — Tony Evans (@TonyEvans92a) 
Before the game, City supporters held banners aloft and donned masks in support of Ranieri prior to Monday’s Premier League home game with Liverpool. 
Ranieri was sacked on Thursday, less than 10 months on from Leicester’s 5,000-1 title triumph, after a run of five straight defeats plunged the club into a relegation battle. 
The bespectacled and avuncular Italian, 65, was dearly loved by Leicester fans and several of those in attendance on Monday made a point of thanking him for his work at the club. 
“Dilly ding, dilly dong/We’re sad Claudio’s gone,” read one banner, a nod to the Ranieri catchphrase that became the slogan of last season’s fairytale title tilt. media_camera A fan is pictured wearing a mask of Leicester City's Italian former manager Claudio Ranieri. media_camera Fans are pictured wearing masks of Leicester City's Italian former manager Claudio Ranieri. ’Thank you Claudio’ media_camera A man walks past a mural of Claudio Ranieri in Leicester city center. 
Many fans wore Ranieri face masks and several banners expressed thanks to him, with one reading: “Thank you Ranieri for making our dreams come true!” One banner held up by a female fan laid the blame for Ranieri’s departure partly at the players’ door: “RANIERI!! YOUR PLAYERS AND OWNERS LET YOU DOWN!” 
Caretaker manager Craig Shakespeare wrote in the match programme that press reports of a player rebellion against Ranieri were “unfair” and “unfounded”. 
Vice-chairman Aiyawatt Srivaddhanaprabha wrote that the players had “supported Claudio fiercely”, but accepted some supporters had been left “angry” by the club’
